article_node.title: How Jet Engine Output Is Measured (No, It's Not By Horsepower)
article_node.summary: Jet engines, introduced in the 1930s, revolutionized air travel by enabling higher speeds, greater altitudes, and larger cargo capacities compared to propeller engines. Their thrust, measured in engine pressure ratio, is generated by converting fuel energy into mechanical energy that drives fan blades. Thrust depends on mass flow rate and velocity difference, and is tested in specialized test cells. Efficiency is affected by altitude and airspeed, with a peak around Mach 3 before diminishing at higher speeds.
